thread.title: Woman complains that she's 'too white' for black people but 'too black' to be white
thread.title_full: Woman complains that she's 'too white' for black people but 'too black' to be white

author: Joshua Barrie
title: Woman complains that she's 'too white' for black people but 'too black' to be white
text:
News Woman complains that she's 'too white' for black people but 'too black' to be white Anita Ronge, who goes by the name of Kasi Mlungu, is a white woman from South Africa who is causing a stir Share Maropong township outside Lephalale, South Africa. Share Get daily   
Oh dear: the Curious Case of Rachel Dolezal has apparently returned in the form of a white woman from South Africa. 
Anita Ronge, who goes by the name of Kasi Mlungu – which means a white person from a predominantly black suburb – has been making waves after comments on racial stereotypes and culture. 
The DJ, 26, recently said these words: "I get rejected for not being 'black enough' and being 'too black' to be white..." Here's Anita... 
Anita plays house music and is a growing face in the South African music scene. Unlike Dolezal, she doesn't, erm, apply lots of fake tan. She looks very white indeed. But she dresses in traditional black African clothing and jewellery in photo shoots, and uses tribal slang. 
Journalist Gaopalelwe Phalaetsile wrote: “Being a black person is not an outfit or attire white people can wear when they see fit, it’s the hardest thing I myself have ever had to be. 
“Blackness comes with socioeconomic circumstances.” 
Scores of others have taken offence. Many have suggested that Anita is simply branding herself to rise to fame and sell music – she's been derided for claiming to be a 'township' (an almost always black, and almost always deprived area) person, when she doesn't come from a township at all. There are arguments to say Anita is romanticizing a culture to which she has no actual ties. Not everyone thinks what Anita is doing is right 
Daily Nhtabi wrote: "That kasimlungu girl is f*
